publisher: Springer Science and Business Media LLC
abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p><jats:italic>Liriomyza huidobrensis</jats:italic> is a leafminer fly and significant horticultural pest. It is a quarantine listed species in many countries and is now present as an established pest in Australia. <jats:italic>Liriomyza huidobrensis</jats:italic> uses a broad range of host plants and has potential for spread into various horticultural systems and regions of Australia. Rapid in-field identification of the pest is critically needed to assist efforts to manage this pest. Morphological identification of the pest is effectively limited to specialist examinations of adult males. Generally, molecular methods such as qPCR and DNA barcoding for identification of <jats:italic>Liriomyza</jats:italic> species require costly laboratory-based hardware. Herein, we developed two independent and rapid LAMP assays targeted to independently inherited mitochondrial and nuclear genes. Both assays are highly sensitive and specific to <jats:italic>L. huidobrensis</jats:italic>. Positive signals can be detected within 10 min on laboratory and portable real-time amplification fluorometers. Further, we adapted these assays for use with colorimetric master mixes, to allow fluorometer free in-field diagnostics of <jats:italic>L. huidobrensis</jats:italic>. Our LAMP assays can be used for stand-alone testing of query specimens and are likely to be essential tools used for rapid identification and monitoring of <jats:italic>L. huidobrensis</jats:italic>.</jats:p>
title: Two independent LAMP assays for rapid identification of the serpentine leafminer, Liriomyza huidobrensis (Blanchard, 1926) (Diptera: Agromyzidae) in Australia
